item.title: Changeset [2870]: Don't rewrite to relative URLs.
item.dc:creator: matt

item.title: Ticket #1618 (TinyMCE won't accept <del> and <ins> tags) updated
item.dc:creator: schulte
item.description:
seth, you'll need to edit the line extended_valid_elements within wp-admin/admin-header.php to include those two tags. I ran into this same issue when I was experimenting with the ​SimpleTags plugin for using the <tag> and <tags> tags.

I wouldn't call it a bug really, but it would be slick if additional tags could be included in that list easily...

item.title: Changeset [2869]: Order scheduled posts by date.
item.dc:creator: matt

item.title: Ticket #1656 (Need more customization of more-link markup) updated
item.dc:creator: Laurabelle
item.description:
Mark,

Neat solution. I like it. Yours is certainly more easily turned into a plugin than mine, which requires direct code editing.

The weakness I see is that it searches for a string that could appear in the text of an entry and (given Murphy's law) will appear at least once. By that time I will, of course, have forgotten all about this code and have no clue what went wrong. Great fun! The problem is easily solvable, but only at the expense of a little elegance. Oh well.

item.title: Ticket #1672 (Support for Technorati Blog Finder) created
item.dc:creator: Ozh
item.description:
An easy improvement suggestion : add rel="tag directory" to internal links pointing to categories (support for ​Technorati Blog Finder)

(This implies trivial changes to add to get_the_category_list() and list_cats() )

item.title: Ticket #1671 (Incorrect Tab Order in Write Post) created
item.dc:creator: skippy
item.description: On the post composition screen, pressing tab from inside the Title field gives focus to the "Save" button. I expect tab to take me to the text entry field.

item.title: Ticket #1670 (Don't get notified of your own comments) created
item.dc:creator: matt
item.description: If the logged in ID of the commenter == to ID of author of post then comment notification shouldn't be sent.

item.title: Ticket #1669 (Patch to "wp_list_pages" to add the opposite of "exclude" (called "only")) updated
item.dc:creator: Fryfrog
item.description:
Added it into a code block to make its formatting "nicer" 

--- wp-includes/template-functions-post.php.old 2005-09-11 09:02:35.000000000 -0400
+++ wp-includes/template-functions-post.php     2005-09-11 08:56:30.000000000 -0400
@@ -287,6 +287,20 @@
                        }
                }
        }
+       if (!empty($r['only'])) {
+               $onlypages = preg_split('/[\s,]+/',$r['only']);
+               if (count($onlypages)) {
+                       foreach ($onlypages as $onlypage) {
+                               if (!empty($exclusions)) {
+                                       $exclusions .= ' OR ';
+                               } else {
+                                       $exclusions .= ' AND ';
+                               }
+                               echo $onlypages[$onlypage];
+                               $exclusions .= ' ID = ' . intval($onlypage) . ' ';
+                       }
+               }
+       }
        $pages = $wpdb->get_results("SELECT * " .
                                                                                                      "FROM $wpdb->posts " .

item.title: Ticket #1669 (Patch to "wp_list_pages" to add the opposite of "exclude" (called "only")) created
item.dc:creator: Fryfrog
item.description:
The diff below will add the opposite functionality of "exclude" to the wp_list_pages. This means instead of excluding all but 1 page, you can choose to ONLY show that one page. This way, no matter what you add in the future it will never have to be messed with to exclude it.

--- wp-includes/template-functions-post.php.old 2005-09-11 09:02:35.000000000 -0400 +++ wp-includes/template-functions-post.php 2005-09-11 08:56:30.000000000 -0400 @@ -287,6 +287,20 @@

}

}

}

+ if (!empty($ronly?)) { + $onlypages = preg_split('/[\s,]+/',$ronly?); + if (count($onlypages)) { + foreach ($onlypages as $onlypage) { + if (!empty($exclusions)) { + $exclusions .= ' OR '; + } else { + $exclusions .= ' AND '; + } + echo $onlypages[$onlypage]; + $exclusions .= ' ID = ' . intval($onlypage) . ' '; + } + } + }

$pages = $wpdb->get_results("SELECT * " .

"FROM $wpdb->posts " .

item.title: Ticket #1668 (pingback xml format is false) created
item.author: Jeena Paradies <spam@…>
item.description:
In /wp-includes/comment-functions.php you send a pingback this way: 

$client->query('pingback.ping', array($pagelinkedfrom, $pagelinkedto) )

so it becomes: 

<?xml version="1.0"?>
<methodCall>
 <methodName>pingback.ping</methodName>
 <params>
  <param><value><array><data>
   <value><string>http://example.org/test.html</string></value>
   <value><string>http://example.org/2005/09/hallo</string></value>
  </data></array></value></param>
 </params>
</methodCall>

The pingback specifications ​http://www.hixie.ch/specs/pingback/pingback says that we need such XML for a valid pingback: 

<?xml version="1.0"?>
<methodCall>
 <methodName>pingback.ping</methodName>
 <params>
  <param><value><string>http://jlog.dev/test.html</string></value></param>
  <param><value><string>http://jlog.dev/2005/09/hallo</string></value></param>
 </params>
</methodCall>

If you call the method this way: 

$client->query('pingback.ping', $pagelinkedfrom, $pagelinkedto)

without the array, it'll send the right XML format.

item.title: Ticket #1632 (duplicate posts) updated
item.dc:creator: tomhanna
item.description: No. This is a new problem. If I were prone to not knowing the difference between click and doubleclick, it wouldn't have started with version 1.5.2.
